title: 110_s552
content: The Act is titled the "Exxon Valdez Oil Spill Tax Treatment Act" and it addresses the tax treatment of income related to the Exxon Valdez litigation. The "Exxon Valdez Oil Spill Tax Treatment Act" allows qualified taxpayers receiving settlement income to elect income averaging for tax purposes under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Exxon Valdez Oil Spill Tax Treatment Act" allows qualified taxpayers to elect income averaging for tax purposes on settlement income under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. This allows for adjustments in taxable income based on elected qualified settlement income. The "Exxon Valdez Oil Spill Tax Treatment Act" allows taxpayers to elect income averaging for settlement income under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The applicable period starts on January 1, 1994, and ends on December 31 of the year the elected qualified settlement income is received. The applicable fraction is the numerator of one divided by the number of years in the applicable period. Elected qualified settlement income is a portion of taxable income for the year. The "Exxon Valdez Oil Spill Tax Treatment Act" allows taxpayers to elect income averaging for settlement income under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Qualified taxpayers receiving settlement income can contribute to retirement accounts up to the amount received during the taxable year. Contributions must be made before the end of the year in which the income was received. Contributions to eligible retirement plans for qualified settlement income must be made by the end of the taxable year to exclude the income from taxable income under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Contributions to eligible retirement plans for qualified settlement income are not considered investments in the contract. The taxpayer will be treated as having received the income in the form of a distribution from the retirement plan. For qualified settlement income, contributions to eligible retirement plans are treated as distributions. Contributions can be made to Roth IRAs or Roth 401(k)s under special rules. Qualified settlement income is taxable and considered an investment in the contract under section 402A of the Internal Revenue Code. Contributions to eligible retirement plans are treated as distributions. Qualified settlement income received by a qualified taxpayer is not considered self-employment income for tax purposes. Qualified taxpayer refers to plaintiffs in the civil action In re Exxon Valdez, No. 89-095-CV (HRH) (Consolidated) (D. Alaska) or beneficiaries of their estate who received qualified settlement income. Qualified settlement income includes income from the same civil action, including interest.
